name: Lost for Words! Quiz | Lyrics Mixture | 10 Questions

questions.text:
This will get you in the swing of things.
"Well it's one for the money, two for the show. 
Three to get ready now go cat go. 
But don't you, step on my ______ suede  shoes"?
questions.explanation:
blue.

	The Elvis Presley, the "King" of rock'n'roll, rocked into the charts with "Blue Suede Shoes" in 1959.  "Blue Suede Shoes" was written by, and originally a hit for, Carl Perkins in 1956.

questions.text:
"Is this the real life? 
Is this just fantasy? 
Caught in a landslide 
No escape from _______."
Which word fits into these lyrics?
questions.explanation:
reality.

	These famous lines come from Queen's "Bohemian Rhapsody", a UK chart topper, peaking at number nine in the US, in 1975. The song lyrics were written by band's front man, Freddie Mercury. This lavish production was produced using around 120 vocal tracks.

questions.text:
What's the missing lyric from this classic tune?
"You are the Dancing Queen, young and sweet, only seventeen. 
Dancing Queen, feel the ______ from the tambourine."
questions.explanation:
beat.

	Pretty obvious really, these lyrics are from ABBA's "Dancing Queen".This track, which features on the "Arrival" album, topped the charts in both the US and UK in 1976. The group got its name from the initial letters of the members' names, A- Agnetha Faltskog, B- Bjorn Ulvaeus, B- Benny Andersson and A- Anni-Frid Lyngstad.

questions.text:
"She told me her name was Billie Jean, as she caused a ______."
Which word fills the gap in this lyric?
questions.explanation:
scene.

	These lines come from Michael Jackson's massive 1983 hit "Billy Jean". Written by Jackson, this song topped the charts on both sides of the Atlantic. "Billy Jean", produced by Quincy Jones, features on the "Thriller" album.

questions.text:
This track's been in the charts several times.
"A long, long time ago. 
I can still remember. 
How that music used to make me ______."
questions.explanation:
smile.

	Originally a hit for Don McLean in 1972, "American Pie" was given a second outing by Madonna in 2000. Madonna's full name is Madonna Louise Ciccone."American Pie" also featured on Madonna's album "Music".

questions.text:
Which word is missing from this well known lyric?
"Ground Control to Major Tom.
Take your protein pills and put your ______ on."
questions.explanation:
helmet.

	These lines are taken from David Bowie's "Space Oddity". This 1969 classic, written by David Bowie, was his first UK hit single. Bowie's birth name is David Jones.

questions.text:
"I read the news today oh boy.
About a ______ man who made the grade."
What's the missing word?
questions.explanation:
lucky.

	This song "A Day in the Life" comes from the Beatles album that changed the face of pop music, "Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band". A 1967 track, "A Day in the Life" was written by John Lennon and Paul McCartney.

questions.text:
These words come from one of the biggest selling records of all time.
"And it seems to me you lived your life 
Like a candle in the wind 
Never knowing who to cling to 
When the ______ set in." 
What's the missing lyric?
questions.explanation:
rain.

	"Candle in the Wind", originally released in 1974, was a song about Marilyn Monroe.  A second version, with new lyrics, was performed by Elton John at Princess Diana's funeral in 1997.  This version has world wide sales of more than 33 million copies.

questions.text:
Can you fill the blank space in this lyric?
"Plenty of ______ at the Hotel California. 
Any time of year, you can find it here."
questions.explanation:
room.

	These lines come from the Eagles classic hit "Hotel California". This 1977 single got to number One in both the US and the UK charts. "Hotel California" won the 1977 Grammy for Record Of The Year.

questions.text:
What's the missing word?
And so I face the final ______."
Finding the missing word on this one should be easy.
questions.explanation:
curtain.

	Probably the most sung song in the world "My Way" was a hit for Frank Sinatra in 1969. The song remained in the UK singles chart for 122 consecutive weeks. Frank Sinatra was given a Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award in 1965.
